verses.text: When they drew near to Jerusalem and came to Bethphage, to the Mount of Olives, Jesus sent two disciples,
verses.comment: Jesus approaches Jerusalem from the Mount of Olives, fulfilling prophecy and setting the stage for His Messianic entrance.

verses.text: saying to them, 'Go into the village opposite you, and at once you will find a donkey tied, and a colt with her. Untie them and bring them to Me.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ instructions fulfill Zechariah 9:9, which describes the Messiah coming humbly on a donkey.

verses.text: 'If anyone says anything to you, you shall say, ‘The Lord has need of them,’ and immediately he will send them.'
verses.comment: Jesus is identified as 'the Lord,' a title signifying authority and divinity, highlighting His sovereignty.

verses.text: This happened so that what was spoken by the prophet might be fulfilled:
verses.comment: Matthew explicitly ties events to the fulfillment of prophecy, emphasizing that Jesus is the awaited Messiah.

verses.text: 'Say to the daughter of Zion, ‘Look, your King is coming to you, humble, and mounted on a donkey, even on a colt, the foal of a beast of burden.’'
verses.comment: The prophecy from Zechariah is quoted nearly verbatim, showing the divine plan unfolding in Jesus’ entrance.

verses.text: The disciples went and did just as Jesus had instructed them.
verses.comment: The obedience of the disciples demonstrates the importance of apostolic faithfulness in carrying out Christ’s will.

verses.text: They brought the donkey and the colt, laid their cloaks on them, and He sat on them.
verses.comment: The laying of cloaks signifies reverence and kingship, recalling ancient enthronement customs.

verses.text: A very great crowd spread their cloaks on the road; others cut branches from the trees and spread them on the road.
verses.comment: The crowd welcomes Jesus as King, reminiscent of royal processions (2 Kings 9:13), marking a significant Messianic claim.

verses.text: The crowds that went ahead of Him and those who followed shouted, 'Hosanna to the Son of David! Blessed is He who comes in the name of the Lord! Hosanna in the highest!'
verses.comment: The crowds recognize Jesus as the 'Son of David,' a Messianic title. 'Hosanna' is a cry for salvation, pointing to His divine mission (cf. Ps. 118:25-26).

verses.text: When He entered Jerusalem, the whole city was stirred, saying, 'Who is this?'
verses.comment: Jerusalem’s excitement parallels earlier scenes at Jesus’ birth, highlighting His identity as a figure of destiny.

verses.text: The crowds answered, 'This is the prophet Jesus from Nazareth in Galilee.'
verses.comment: Though Jesus is acknowledged as a prophet, the full implications of His divine Sonship remain to be revealed throughout the chapter.

verses.text: Jesus entered the temple and drove out all those who were buying and selling in the temple, and overturned the tables of the money changers and the seats of those who sold doves.
verses.comment: Jesus’ action fulfills the zeal prophesied in Scripture (Ps. 69:9) and asserts His authority over the temple, God’s house.

verses.text: He said to them, 'It is written, ‘My house shall be called a house of prayer,’ but you have made it a den of robbers.'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Isaiah and Jeremiah, calling back to the Old Testament desire for pure worship and the warning against corrupt religion.

verses.text: The blind and the lame came to Him in the temple, and He healed them.
verses.comment: Jesus’ healings in the temple fulfill Messianic expectations from Isaiah—the restoration of sight and walking—a sign of divine intervention.

verses.text: But when the chief priests and the scribes saw the wonderful things that He did, and the children crying out in the temple, ‘Hosanna to the Son of David!’ they were indignant,
verses.comment: Religious authorities react with hostility to Jesus being praised as Messiah, despite His miraculous works—a recurring theme of spiritual blindness.

verses.text: and they said to Him, 'Do You hear what these are saying?' Jesus said to them, 'Yes. Have you never read, ‘Out of the mouth of infants and nursing babies You have prepared praise’?'
verses.comment: Jesus applies Psalm 8:2 to Himself, receiving divine praise—even from children—affirming His identity as worthy of worship.

verses.text: He left them, went out of the city to Bethany, and spent the night there.
verses.comment: Jesus often retreats after significant events to pray. Bethany serves as a place of rest, symbolic of communion before upcoming trials.

verses.text: In the morning, as He was returning to the city, He became hungry.
verses.comment: Jesus’ hunger attests to His full humanity, even as His miracles show divinity—a key aspect of orthodox Christology.

verses.text: Seeing a fig tree by the road, He came to it but found nothing on it except leaves. And He said to it, 'Let no fruit ever grow on you again.' Immediately the fig tree withered.
verses.comment: The fig tree symbolizes Israel’s spiritual barrenness; the withering acts as a prophetic sign of judgment for unfruitfulness.

verses.text: When the disciples saw it, they marveled, saying, 'How did the fig tree wither at once?'
verses.comment: The disciples’ astonishment at Jesus’ authority over creation reinforces His identity as both true man and true God.

verses.text: Jesus answered them, 'Truly, I say to you, if you have faith and do not doubt, you will not only do what has been done to the fig tree, but even if you say to this mountain, ‘Be taken up and cast into the sea,’ it will happen.'
verses.comment: Jesus teaches about the extraordinary power of faith, inviting believers to trust in God’s working, often linked with the necessity of perseverance in prayer.

verses.text: And whatever you ask in prayer, if you believe, you will receive.'
verses.comment: Faith-filled prayer is effectual. The emphasis here presupposes a faithful relationship with God, often connected to sacramental practice and unity.

verses.text: When He came into the temple, the chief priests and elders of the people confronted Him as He was teaching, and said, 'By what authority are You doing these things, and who gave You this authority?'
verses.comment: Religious leaders question Jesus’ authority—His power comes directly from God, not derived from human institution, yet fulfills legitimate office.

verses.text: Jesus answered them, 'I also will ask you one thing. If you tell Me the answer, then I also will tell you by what authority I do these things.'
verses.comment: Jesus answers with a counter-question, a teaching method that often exposes the interlocutors’ motives and challenges their sincerity.

verses.text: 'The baptism of John, from where did it come? From heaven or from men?' They discussed it among themselves, saying, 'If we say, “From heaven,” He will say to us, “Then why did you not believe him?”'
verses.comment: John’s baptism is presented as a heavenly institution, showing a continuity of divine mission that culminates in Christ.

verses.text: But if we say, ‘From men,’ we fear the crowd, for all hold John as a prophet.'
verses.comment: Their fear of the people reveals their lack of true spiritual authority, being motivated more by human approval than divine truth.

verses.text: So they answered Jesus, 'We do not know.' And He said to them, 'Neither will I tell you by what authority I do these things.'
verses.comment: Because of their insincerity, Jesus withholds further revelation, confirming that openness to God is crucial for greater understanding.

verses.text: 'But what do you think? A man had two sons; and he went to the first and said, “Son, go and work in the vineyard today.”'
verses.comment: The vineyard is an Old Testament symbol for Israel (Isa. 5:1-7), setting up a lesson about obedience and authentic faith.

verses.text: 'He answered, ‘I will not,’ but afterwards he changed his mind and went.'
verses.comment: Repentance is highlighted—the true son is the one who ultimately does the Father’s will, paralleling the teaching on contrition and confession.

verses.text: 'He went to the other son and said the same. He answered, ‘I go, sir,’ but did not go.'
verses.comment: Lip service is contrasted with heartfelt obedience—real righteousness is shown through action, not just words.

verses.text: 'Which of the two did the will of his father?' They said, 'The first.' Jesus said to them, 'Truly I tell you, the tax collectors and the prostitutes are entering the kingdom of God ahead of you.'
verses.comment: Jesus points to the transformative power of repentance; outwardly sinful but repentant people precede the self-righteous in the kingdom.

verses.text: 'For John came to you in the way of righteousness, and you did not believe him; but the tax collectors and prostitutes believed him. Even when you saw it, you did not afterward repent and believe him.'
verses.comment: Jesus rebukes the leaders for their unrepentance—faith involves openness to conversion and actual amendment of life.

verses.text: 'Hear another parable: There was a master of a house who planted a vineyard, put a fence around it, dug a winepress in it, and built a tower, and leased it to tenants, and went into another country.'
verses.comment: Echoes Isaiah’s parable of the vineyard; God has carefully prepared and entrusted Israel to leaders who are meant to bear fruit.

verses.text: 'When the season for fruit drew near, he sent his servants to the tenants to get his fruit.'
verses.comment: The master’s servants symbolize the prophets sent by God to call Israel to faithfulness.

verses.text: 'But the tenants took his servants and beat one, killed another, and stoned another.'
verses.comment: The persistent rejection and persecution of the prophets are a significant theme through Israel’s history.

verses.text: 'Again, he sent other servants, more than the first, and they did the same to them.'
verses.comment: This repeated effort reveals God’s patient mercy and ongoing call to repentance—a pattern seen in both Old and New Testament history.

verses.text: 'Last of all, he sent his son to them, saying, ‘They will respect my son.’'
verses.comment: Here, the Son represents Jesus Himself, God’s final and fullest revelation (Heb. 1:1–2), distinguished from previous messengers.

verses.text: 'But when the tenants saw the son, they said to themselves, “This is the heir. Come, let us kill him and have his inheritance.”'
verses.comment: A foreshadowing of the plot to kill Jesus for perceived gain—pointing toward the rejection of God’s chosen and the mystery of the crucifixion.

verses.text: 'So they took him and threw him out of the vineyard and killed him.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ crucifixion outside Jerusalem is prophetically signified; He suffers outside the gates, sanctifying the people by His blood.

verses.text: 'When therefore the owner of the vineyard comes, what will he do to those tenants?'
verses.comment: A rhetorical question; divine judgment is implied, and the focus shifts to accountability for stewardship.

verses.text: They said to Him, 'He will put those wretches to a miserable death and lease the vineyard to others who will give him the fruits in their seasons.'
verses.comment: The leaders pronounce judgment on themselves, prefiguring the transfer of the kingdom to a new people—those who bear spiritual fruit.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'Have you never read in the Scriptures: “The stone that the builders rejected has become the cornerstone; this was the Lord’s doing, and it is marvelous in our eyes”?'
verses.comment: Jesus identifies Himself as the cornerstone prophesied in Psalm 118, the foundation on which God’s household is built.

verses.text: 'Therefore I tell you, the kingdom of God will be taken away from you and given to a people producing its fruits.'
verses.comment: Jesus foretells the transfer of divine favor to those who will faithfully serve and remain in unity and obedience to God’s kingdom.

verses.text: 'Whoever falls on this stone will be broken to pieces; but on whomever it falls, it will crush him.'
verses.comment: The stone—Christ—can be a foundation or a stumbling block; final judgment belongs to Him who has all authority.

verses.text: When the chief priests and the Pharisees heard His parables, they perceived that He was speaking about them.
verses.comment: Jesus’ parables expose leaders’ failures; self-awareness should lead to repentance, and prepared hearts receive the kingdom.

verses.text: They sought to arrest Him, but they feared the crowds, because the people considered Him a prophet.
verses.comment: Opposition intensifies, but the crowd’s esteem for Jesus provides a temporary shielding. His divinity, authority, and perfection of the prophets is underscored here.
